title: Portrait of the Marchioness of Santa Cruz
text:
The Portrait of the Marchioness of Santa Cruz or Portrait of the Marquise of Santa Cruz is an 1805 portrait by the <a href="Spain">Spanish</a> artist <a href="Francisco%20Jos%C3%A9%20de%20Goya%20y%20Lucientes">Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes</a>, a family friend of the subject. It has been owned by the <a href="Museo%20del%20Prado">Museo del Prado</a> since 1986, when it bought it from its previous owner for over <a href="US%24">US$</a>6 million.
It shows <a href="Joaquina%20T%C3%A9llez-Gir%C3%B3n%2C%20Marquise%20of%20Santa%20Cruz">Joaquina Téllez-Girón, Marquise of Santa Cruz</a> clad in a very light white <a href="dress">dress</a>, lying sideways on a red <a href="divan">divan</a>. Her head is decorated with yellow <a href="flower">flower</a>s; her left hand is balancing a <a href="lyre-guitar">lyre-guitar</a>. Her gaze does not directly fix on the viewer but seems to look distant. Her body does not seem to sit in a natural position, but seemingly floats on the red divan and the <a href="pillow">pillow</a>s. 
The theme seems almost <a href="allegory">allegorical</a>, a reference to the ancient Greek theatre. The composition of the work is similar to <a href="Antonio%20Canova">Antonio Canova</a>'s sculpture of <a href="Venus%20Victrix%20%28Canova%29">"Paolina Borghese as Venus Victrix"</a>. The portrait is also similar to <a href="Diego%20Vel%C3%A1zquez">Diego Velázquez</a> and, to an extent, to <a href="Titian">Titian</a>'s depictions of <a href="Venus">Venus</a>. The flowers on her head are a reference to <a href="Dionysus">Bacchus</a>, while the lyre-guitar with its resemblance to the ancient <a href="lyre">lyre</a> is a homage to art and <a href="Apollo">Apollo</a>.
This painting inspired one <a href="pastiche">pastiche</a> or fantasy portrait depicted in the comedy film "<a href="Mortdecai%20%28film%29">Mortdecai</a>" (2015), starring <a href="Johnny%20Depp">Johnny Depp</a> and <a href="Gwyneth%20Paltrow">Gwyneth Paltrow</a>.
